page.title: 19ROMSLEY,HISTORY OF.
page.content: Romsley is on a range of low hills known as the Clents.The original village was known as St.Kenelmstowe and was built near the Saxon church 2 km to the west.Nothing remains of this village.A Celtic fort site on Clent shows habitation in pre-Roman times.The old salt way from Droitwich north goes thro' east of village. The boy king of Mercia,St.Kenelm is said to have been murdered,by order of his sister,near the Saxon church.A spring, still there,is said to have marked the site.Part of the woodland known as Ellwood owned by the Prison Service and used by the villagers is part of the great forest of Feckenham. Older part is deciduous mainly coppiced oak,birch and hazel.Some new tree planting including conifers has taken place.The ruined abbey of Hales Owen is just N of the area.
